conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the blocks in both scenarios to determine the friction force in the second scenario.
Block A is just resting on the inclined plane at θ = 37°.
The component of the gravitational force along the incline is balanced by the frictional force.
Forces on block A: gravitational force \( Mg \), normal force \( N \), frictional force \( f \).
Component of gravitational force along incline is \( Mg \sin 37^\circ \).
Normal force is \( N = Mg \cos 37^\circ \).
Frictional force \( f = Mg \sin 37^\circ = 0.6Mg \).
Maximum static frictional force is \( f_{\text{max}} = \mu_s Mg \cdot 0.8 \).
Calculate \( \mu_s = \frac{0.6}{0.8} = 0.75 \).
Angle changes to θ = 30° and a smooth cylinder B is placed between A and the inclined plane.
Component of gravitational force along incline is \( Mg \sin 30^\circ = 0.5Mg \).
Normal force from incline is \( N_1 = Mg \cos 30^\circ - N_{AB} \).
Cylinder B is smooth, so it does not exert any frictional force on A.
Maximum static frictional force is \( f_{\text{max}} = 0.75 (0.866Mg - N_{AB}) \).
Frictional force must balance the component of gravitational force: \( f = 0.5Mg \).
Given \( M = 4m \).
Normal force \( N_{AB} = 0.866 \cdot \frac{M}{4}g = 0.2165Mg \).
Normal force from incline is \( N_1 = 0.866Mg - 0.2165Mg = 0.6495Mg \).
Frictional force is \( f = 0.75 \cdot 0.6495Mg = 0.487125Mg \approx 0.5Mg \).
The friction force of A on the slope is \( \boxed{2mg} \).
